summary: The text discusses the sufferings of the Jews under Antiochus as recounted in the history of the Maccabees. It describes their bravery in defending the law of God against persecution, flames, swords, and eventual martyrdom. This period is compared to the anticipated trials under the Antichrist, where many will resist his power. The text also references the Jewish uprising during the final destruction of the Temple under Vespasian and Titus, noting that many knew their Lord and died for their faith. It mentions Mathathias of Modin, who rebelled against Antiochus's forces and tried to preserve true worship, viewing his short-lived rebellion as 'small help.' His son Judas Maccabeus and his brothers continued the fight but were eventually defeated through betrayal.
